text: in 1839 gravediggers found a lead coffin
just over there and when they looked
inside there's one small bone which
turned to dust but they found this full
head of hair complete with the plat it
was resting on this piece of wood we
think this is oak the white bits I'm
told are what remains of the scalp and
the scientists in Oxford have been
trying to find out more about it and
what they have established is it dates
back to around the nine hundreds so
Saxon times archaeological scientists
took a sample from the hair if you look
closely you can see those bits of scalp
and this is the lab at Oxford
University's Redax cluster this is one
of the samples being prepared for
testing the tests have established that
the person whose hair this was died and
therefore lived in Saxon times he or she
probably ate fish and there was pine
resin on the hair Romsey Abi's
archaeological adviser says it could be
the hair of Saint Ethel flater the ABA's
patron saint then again it might not be
it it's the mystery of the saxon hair in
the lead coffin from BBC Radio 4's
Broadcasting House
